channel.title: Variable tutorial (including doubles)

item.title: Variable tutorial (including doubles)
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

Double != double
Integer != int
etc and so forth, use the primitive type not the class.

Most shit tutorial on MoparScape, if they want to learn variables in Java they should Google or look at Oracles tutorials. They didn’t spend countless hours writing them so someone that doesn’t understand them can “reteach” wrongly. That reminds me of a quote.

“If you can’t explain it simply, you don’t know it well enough.”

Read full topic

item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

You can’t be serious. Variable declarations should be lower case, you shouldn’t use the class form of double, you should be using the type, you should use code tags, actually give the proper access modifiers and conventions for an application, AND FOR THE LOVE OF GOD ACTUALLY TEACH US SOMETHING, this is useless, and wrong.

item.title: Variable tutorial (including doubles)
item.dc:creator: @zach55200 zach55200
item.description:
@zach55200 wrote:

Welcome to my first tutorial. I’m going to explain variables using doubles for the people out there don’t already know how to.

Variables are place holders for something. Here’s an example

	x = 294

x is taking the value of 294, x now stands for 294.

We can apply variables now that we know what they do.
When using doubles, this will allow us to use decimals.

Example:

class tutorial{ public static void main(String args[]){ Double Variable;//Assigns the variable a name Variable = 2.2;//assigns the variable value 
	System.out.print(Variable);//Prints the variable out
}

}

Now this is how to assign a variable without a decimal. We will be using something call an int, int is short for integer. Or a whole number. It can go from a negative number to a positive number, but can’t have a decimal.

class tutorial{ public static void main(String args[]){ int Variable;//Assigns variable Variable = 22;//Gives the value 
	System.out.print(Variable);//Prints out on screen
}

}

I hope this helped. If you have questions or think I left something out, please let me know.

Also check this out if you’re confused or want to know more.
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/variables.html follow the tutorial

Thanks for the link, Matzie

Read full topic
